docs.lead_paragraph: Serenading The Earth As a singer, Tom Chapin has an unusual distinction: one of his hit recordings has been played not only all over the world but also more than 300 miles above it. '' 'This Pretty Planet' was one of the songs used on Discovery to wake up the astronauts -- John Glenn and the boys,'' Mr. Chapin said, referring to Senator Glenn's 1998 voyage on the space shuttle.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bitter Partisan Fight Brewing Over Medicare Drug Benefits'' (front page, April 5): Relying on government control at one end of the spectrum, or practicing laissez-faire at the other end of the spectrum, are only temporary Band-Aids to a deeper and more insidious disease: Just why are prescription drugs so expensive? PANKAJ GUPTA, M.D. Framingham, Mass., April 5, 2000
docs.abstract: Dr Panjak Gupta letter comments on April 5 article on bitter partisan fight looming over Medicare drug benefits (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cancer patients and others with severe pain who live in black, Asian and Hispanic neighborhoods may have trouble getting medicine for their pain, because their local pharmacies often do not stock morphine and related drugs, doctors are reporting. A survey of 347 pharmacies in New York City found that in nonwhite neighborhoods, only 25 percent of pharmacies had enough morphine-like drugs, or opioids, to treat severe pain. But in white neighborhoods, 72 percent of the stores had adequate supplies. Although the survey was conducted in New York, interviews with pharmacists and doctors in Los Angeles, Chicago, Minneapolis and Detroit suggested similar problems in those cities.

headline.main: Little Access to Pain Drugs in Some Areas

docs.abstract: Doctors report patients in minority neighborhoods have trouble getting medicine for their pain, because local pharmacies often do not stock morphine and related drugs; survey of 347 pharmacies in New York City finds that in nonwhite neighborhoods, only 25 percent of them have enough morphine-like drugs, or opioids, to treat severe pain, while in white neighborhoods, 72 percent of stores have adequate supplies; similar problems are thought to exist in other large cities; druggists who do not carry medicines blame law demand, onerous regulations and fear of theft; some doctors suggest real culprit is subtle form of racial bias (M)
docs.snippet: Cancer patients and others with severe pain who live in black, Asian and Hispanic neighborhoods may have trouble getting medicine for their pain, because their local pharmacies often do not stock morphine and related drugs, doctors are reporting.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicaid money designated for disabled poor children has been siphoned off by consulting firms and state governments, federal investigators said today. In a new report on Medicaid in schools, the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, described many ''improper payments,'' accused schools of overstating their Medicaid costs and said the problems had been allowed to fester because of weak supervision by federal Medicaid officials.

headline.main: Consultants and States Siphon Millions in Medicaid for Young, Inquiry Says

docs.abstract: GAO report on Medicaid in schools charges that hundreds of millions of dollars designated for disabled children is siphoned off by consulting firms and state governments; says schools overstate Medicaid costs and federal officials provide lax supervision; districts often pay private firms to prepare Medicaid claims and then bill Medicaid, in violation of law; Timothy W Westmoreland, top Medicaid official, accepts findings; schools in 47 states got $2.3 billion in Medicaid payments for school-based health services last year; improper charges noted (M)
docs.snippet: Hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicaid money designated for disabled poor children has been siphoned off by consulting firms and state governments, federal investigators said today.    In a new report on Medicaid in schools, the General...

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven months before Election Day, the struggle over expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs for the elderly is escalating, with both parties maneuvering furiously on an issue that matters, deeply, to a critical group of voters. As the debate over the Republican budget resolution began today in the Senate, for example, Democrats were pushing for an amendment that would require the creation of a Medicare drug benefit before any tax cut could take effect.

headline.main: Bitter Partisan Fight Brewing Over Medicare Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: Partisan struggle over expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs is escalating, as both parties maneuver furiously on issue of deep importance to crucial group of voters; graphs; Senate begins debate on budget resolution with Democrats proposing amendment that would require Medicare drug benefit before any tax cut; Pres Clinton backs measure; Republican leader Trent Lott says Republicans are committed to benefit; Canadian system is becoming embroiled in debate, as Democratic candidates cross border to showcase lower drug prices; drug industry counters with ads on shortcomings of Canadian health system; Hosue Republicans scramble to produce their own drug plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: William R. Hamilton, a Democratic political consultant and pollster who worked in more than 400 election campaigns, including four for president, died on Saturday at a hospital in Fernandina Beach, Fla. He was 61 and lived on nearby Amelia Island. The cause was lung cancer, said David A. Beattie, Mr. Hamilton's partner in the firm of Hamilton Beattie & Staff.

headline.main: William Hamilton, 61, a Top Pollster for Democratic Candidates

docs.abstract: William R Hamilton, Democratic political consultant and pollster, dies at age 61 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans reluctant to answer questions in the long-form census wonder: who gets access to this private information? Though misplaced against the census takers, this suspicion reflects a growing sense that our lives are too often open books. The most feared gossips are the federal government, conglomerating industries and Internet marketers. The feds are supposedly restrained by the Privacy Act of 1974. But the same Pentagon that gleefully made public Linda Tripp's file containing a teenage arrest record now cites privacy concerns in refusing to identify the male general accused of making a pass at the highest-ranking female officer. Rank -- and now sex -- hath its privilege.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column says there is growing sense in nation that citizens have no privacy; says worse encroachers on personal privacy are federal government, merged corporate empires that pool information, and stalkers of computerized marketing; says new privacy laws are needed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OPENING an ''explanation of benefits'' letter from a health insurance company is a little like playing blackjack in a casino: Chances are you're going to lose; the question is how much. While the majority of Americans insured through their employers are now enrolled in H.M.O.'s, and thus make minimal co-payments on doctor's visits, a lot of us -- me included -- still get medical care the old-fashioned way, paying the doctor up front, filing a claim and waiting for reimbursement. The same system applies to patients in preferred provider plans who choose to see doctors outside the network.

headline.main: Reasonable and Customary, But in Whose Eyes?

docs.abstract: Money & Medicine column by Jennifer Steinhauer discusses advantages, for those not in managed care, of establishing flexible medical spending account--plan that lets pretax dollars be set aside for paying medical bills; says one drawback is that any money set aside must be spent in that year, or lost at end of year; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Immigrant workers, a huge but often voiceless group, were given a chance to speak up yesterday, and speak they did: about abuses on the job, about mandatory 70-hour weeks, about not being allowed to take bathroom breaks, about making just $2 an hour. These workers were given their soapbox at an unusual forum sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which is seeking to persuade millions of immigrant workers to join unions, though labor has long turned a cold shoulder to them.

headline.main: Immigrants Flock to Union Banner at a Forum

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO sponsors forum in New York at which immigrant workers describe abuses on the job (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE house-hunting in Fayetteville, N.C., a few months ago, Suzanne and Curtis Walker found themselves in an enviable quandary: they had discovered the expansive ranch house they were dreaming of, yet were reluctant to sell their investments to buy it because the stock market was performing so well. They managed to hang on to both the house and their portfolio -- by qualifying for a 30-year loan without having to put a penny down, aside from closing costs.

headline.main: Zero Down, And Maybe Something To Gain

docs.abstract: Growing number of lenders are offering mortgages that do not require down payments, though with rates half to full percentage point above those of conventional mortgages; zero-down loans were virtually impossible just few years ago, but lenders now face more competition and dwindling refinancing market because of higher interest rates; photo (M)
